ol.li: Understand the definitions of one-to-one and onto transformations.
Recipes: verify whether a matrix transformation is one-to-one and/or onto.
Pictures: examples of matrix transformations that are/are not one-to-one and/or onto.

introduction.p: In this section, we discuss two of the most basic questions one can ask about a transformation: whether it is one-to-one and/or onto. For a matrix transformation, we translate these questions into the language of matrices.

subsection.title: One-to-one Transformations

statement.p: A transformation T\colon\R^n\to\R^m is one-to-one if, for every vector b in \R^m, the equation T(x)=b has at most one solution x in \R^n.

remark.p: Another word for one-to-one is injective.

example.title: Functions of one variable
example.p: The function \sin\colon\R\to\R is not one-to-one. Indeed, \sin(0) = \sin(\pi) = 0, so the inputs 0 and \pi have the same output 0. In fact, the equation \sin(x) = 0 has infinitely many solutions \ldots,-2\pi,-\pi,0,\pi,2\pi,\ldots.

The function \exp\colon\R\to\R defined by \exp(x) = e^x is one-to-one. Indeed, if T(x) = T(y), then e^x = e^y, so \ln(e^x) = \ln(e^y), and hence x = y. The equation T(x) = C has one solution x = \ln(C) if C > 0, and it has zero solutions if C\leq 0.
The function f\colon\R\to\R defined by f(x)=x^3 is one-to-one. Indeed, if f(x) = f(y) then x^3 = y^3; taking cube roots gives x = y. In other words, the only solution of f(x) = C is x=\sqrt[3]C.

The function f\colon\R\to\R defined by f(x)=x^3-x is not one-to-one. Indeed, f(0) = f(1) = f(-1) = 0, so the inputs 0,1,-1 all have the same output 0. The solutions of the equation x^3 - x = 0 are exactly the roots of f(x) = x(x-1)(x+1), and this equation has three roots.

The function f\colon\R\to\R defined by f(x)=x^2 is not one-to-one. Indeed, f(1) = 1 = f(-1), so the inputs 1 and -1 have the same outputs. The function g\colon\R\to\R defined by g(x)=|x| is not one-to-one for the same reason.

example.title: A real-word transformation: robotics

statement.p:
Let A be an m\times n matrix, and let T(x)=Ax be the associated matrix transformation. The following statements are equivalent:
T is one-to-one.
For every b in \R^m, the equation T(x)=b has at most one solution.
For every b in \R^m, the equation Ax=b has a unique solution or is inconsistent.
Ax=0 has only the trivial solution.
The columns of A are linearly independent.
A has a pivot in every column.
The range of T has dimension n.

proof.p: Statements 1, 2, and 3 are translations of each other. The equivalence of 3 and 4 follows from this : if Ax=0 has only one solution, then Ax=b has only one solution as well, or it is inconsistent. The equivalence of 4, 5, and 6 is a consequence of this , and the equivalence of 6 and 7 follows from the fact that the rank of a matrix is equal to the number of columns with pivots.

subsection.p: Recall that equivalent means that, for a given matrix, either all of the statements are true simultaneously, or they are all false.

example.title: A matrix transformation that is one-to-one

statement.p: Let A be the matrix A = \mat{1 0; 0 1; 1 0}, and define T\colon\R^2\to\R^3 by T(x) = Ax. Is T one-to-one?

solution.p: The reduced row echelon form of A is \mat{1 0; 0 1; 0 0}. Hence A has a pivot in every column, so T is one-to-one.

figure.caption: A picture of the matrix transformation T. As you drag the input vector on the left side, you see that different input vectors yield different output vectors on the right side.

example.title: A matrix transformation that is not one-to-one

statement.p: Let A = \mat{1 0 0; 0 1 0; 0 0 0}, and define T\colon\R^3\to\R^3 by T(x) = Ax. Is T one-to-one? If not, find two different vectors u,v such that T(u)=T(v).

solution.p: The matrix A is already in reduced row echelon form. It does not have a pivot in every column, so T is not one-to-one. Therefore, we know from the that Ax=0 has nontrivial solutions. If v is a nontrivial (i.e., nonzero) solution of Av = 0, then T(v) = Av = 0 = A0 = T(0), so 0 and v are different vectors with the same output. For instance, T\vec{0 0 1} = \mat{1 0 0; 0 1 0; 0 0 0}\vec{0 0 1} = 0 = T\vec{0 0 0}.

Geometrically, T is projection onto the xy-plane. Any two vectors that lie on the same vertical line will have the same projection. For b on the xy-plane, the solution set of T(x) = b is the entire vertical line containing b. In particular, T(x) = b has infinitely many solutions.

figure.caption: A picture of the matrix transformation T. The transformation T projects a vector onto the xy-plane. The violet line is the solution set of T(x)=0. If you drag x along the violet line, the output T(x) = Ax does not change. This demonstrates that T(x)=0 has more than one solution, so T is not one-to-one.

example.title: A matrix transformation that is not one-to-one

statement.p: Let A be the matrix A = \mat{1 1 0; 0 1 1}, and define T\colon\R^3\to\R^2 by T(x) = Ax. Is T one-to-one? If not, find two different vectors u,v such that T(u)=T(v).

solution.p:
The reduced row echelon form of A is \mat{1 0 -1; 0 1 1}. There is not a pivot in every column, so T is not one-to-one. Therefore, we know from the that Ax=0 has nontrivial solutions. If v is a nontrivial (i.e., nonzero) solution of Av = 0, then T(v) = Av = 0 = A0 = T(0), so 0 and v are different vectors with the same output. In order to find a nontrivial solution, we find the parametric form of the solutions of Ax=0 using the reduced matrix above: \syseq{x \+ \. - z = 0; \. \+ y + z = 0} \quad\implies\quad \syseq{x = z; y = -z}
The free variable is z. Taking z=1 gives the nontrivial solution T\vec{1 -1 1} = \mat{1 1 0; 0 1 1}\vec{1 -1 1} = 0 = T\vec{0 0 0}.

figure.caption: A picture of the matrix transformation T. The violet line is the null space of A, i.e., solution set of T(x)=0. If you drag x along the violet line, the output T(x) = Ax does not change. This demonstrates that T(x)=0 has more than one solution, so T is not one-to-one.

example.title: A matrix transformation that is not one-to-one

statement.p: Let A = \mat{1 -1 2; -2 2 -4}, and define T\colon\R^3\to\R^2 by T(x) = Ax. Is T one-to-one? If not, find two different vectors u,v such that T(u)=T(v).

solution.p: The reduced row echelon form of A is \mat{1 -1 2; 0 0 0}. There is not a pivot in every column, so T is not one-to-one. Therefore, we know from the that Ax=0 has nontrivial solutions. If v is a nontrivial (i.e., nonzero) solution of Av = 0, then T(v) = Av = 0 = A0 = T(0), so 0 and v are different vectors with the same output. In order to find a nontrivial solution, we find the parametric form of the solutions of Ax=0 using the reduced matrix above: x - y + 2z = 0 \quad\implies\quad x = y - 2z. The free variables are y and z. Taking y=1 and z=0 gives the nontrivial solution T\vec{1 1 0} = \mat{1 -1 2; -2 2 -4}\vec{1 1 0} = 0 = T\vec{0 0 0}.

figure.caption: A picture of the matrix transformation T. The violet plane is the solution set of T(x)=0. If you drag x along the violet plane, the output T(x) = Ax does not change. This demonstrates that T(x)=0 has more than one solution, so T is not one-to-one.

subsection.p: One-to-onefinding two vectors with the same image The previous three examples can be summarized as follows. Suppose that T(x)=Ax is a matrix transformation that is not one-to-one. By the , there is a nontrivial solution of Ax=0. This means that the null space of A is not the zero space. All of the vectors in the null space are solutions to T(x)=0. If you compute a nonzero vector v in the null space (by row reducing and finding the parametric form of the solution set of Ax=0, for instance), then v and 0 both have the same output: T(v) = Av = 0 = T(0).

note.title: Wide matrices do not have one-to-one transformations
note.p: If T\colon\R^n\to\R^m is a one-to-one matrix transformation, what can we say about the relative sizes of n and m?

The matrix associated to T has n columns and m rows. Each row and each column can only contain one pivot, so in order for A to have a pivot in every column, it must have at least as many rows as columns: n\leq m.
This says that, for instance, \R^3 is too big to admit a one-to-one linear transformation into \R^2.

subsection.title: Onto Transformations

statement.p: A transformation T\colon\R^n\to\R^m is onto if, for every vector b in \R^m, the equation T(x)=b has at least one solution x in \R^n.

remark.p: Another word for onto is surjective.

example.title: Functions of one variable
example.p: The function \sin\colon\R\to\R is not onto. Indeed, taking b=2, the equation \sin(x)=2 has no solution. The range of \sin is the closed interval [-1,1], which is smaller than the codomain \R.

The function \exp\colon\R\to\R defined by \exp(x) = e^x is not onto. Indeed, taking b=-1, the equation \exp(x) = e^x = -1 has no solution. The range of \exp is the set (0,\infty) of all positive real numbers.
The function f\colon\R\to\R defined by f(x)=x^3 is onto. Indeed, the equation f(x) = x^3 = b always has the solution x = \sqrt[3]b.

The function f\colon\R\to\R defined by f(x)=x^3-x is onto. Indeed, the solutions of the equation f(x) = x^3 - x = b are the roots of the polynomial x^3 - x - b; as this is a cubic polynomial, it has at least one real root.

example.title: A real-word transformation: robotics
example.p: The robot arm transformation of this is not onto. The robot cannot reach objects that are very far away.

statement.p:
Let A be an m\times n matrix, and let T(x)=Ax be the associated matrix transformation. The following statements are equivalent:
T is onto.
T(x)=b has at least one solution for every b in \R^m.
Ax=b is consistent for every b in \R^m.
The columns of A span \R^m.
A has a pivot in every row.
The range of T has dimension m.

proof.p: Statements 1, 2, and 3 are translations of each other. The equivalence of 3, 4, 5, and 6 follows from this .

example.title: A matrix transformation that is onto

statement.p: Let A be the matrix A = \mat{1 1 0; 0 1 1}, and define T\colon\R^3\to\R^2 by T(x) = Ax. Is T onto?

solution.p: The reduced row echelon form of A is \mat{1 0 -1; 0 1 1}. Hence A has a pivot in every row, so T is onto.

figure.caption: A picture of the matrix transformation T. Every vector on the right side is the output of T for a suitable input. If you drag b, the demo will find an input vector x with output b.

example.title: A matrix transformation that is not onto

statement.p: Let A be the matrix A = \mat{1 0; 0 1; 1 0}, and define T\colon\R^2\to\R^3 by T(x) = Ax. Is T onto? If not, find a vector b in \R^3 such that T(x)=b has no solution.

solution.p: The reduced row echelon form of A is \mat{1 0; 0 1; 0 0}. Hence A does not have a pivot in every row, so T is not onto. In fact, since T\vec{x y} = \mat{1 0; 0 1; 1 0}\vec{x y} = \vec{x y x}, we see that for every output vector of T, the third entry is equal to the first. Therefore, b=(1,2,3) is not in the range of T.

figure.caption: A picture of the matrix transformation T. The range of T is the violet plane on the right; this is smaller than the codomain \R^3. If you drag b off of the violet plane, then the equation Ax=b becomes inconsistent; this means T(x)=b has no solution.

example.title: A matrix transformation that is not onto

statement.p: Let A = \mat{1 -1 2; -2 2 -4}, and define T\colon\R^3\to\R^2 by T(x) = Ax. Is T onto? If not, find a vector b in \R^2 such that T(x)=b has no solution.

solution.p: The reduced row echelon form of A is \mat{1 -1 2; 0 0 0}. There is not a pivot in every row, so T is not onto. The range of T is the column space of A, which is equal to \Span\left\{\vec{1 -2},\;\vec{-1 2},\;\vec{2 -4}\right\} = \Span\left\{\vec{1 -2}\right\}, since all three columns of A are collinear. Therefore, any vector not on the line through 1\choose-2 is not in the range of T. For instance, if b={1\choose 1} then T(x)=b has no solution.

figure.caption: A picture of the matrix transformation T. The range of T is the violet line on the right; this is smaller than the codomain \R^2. If you drag b off of the violet line, then the equation Ax=b becomes inconsistent; this means T(x)=b has no solution.

subsection.p: Ontofinding a vector not in the range The previous two examples illustrate the following observation. Suppose that T(x)=Ax is a matrix transformation that is not onto. This means that \text{range}(T) = \Col(A) is a subspace of \R^m of dimension less than m: perhaps it is a line in the plane, or a line in 3-space, or a plane in 3-space, etc. Whatever the case, the range of T is very small compared to the codomain. To find a vector not in the range of T, choose a random nonzero vector b in \R^m; you have to be extremely unlucky to choose a vector that is in the range of T. Of course, to check whether a given vector b is in the range of T, you have to solve the matrix equation Ax=b to see whether it is consistent.

note.title: Tall matrices do not have onto transformations
note.p: If T\colon\R^n\to\R^m is an onto matrix transformation, what can we say about the relative sizes of n and m?

The matrix associated to T has n columns and m rows. Each row and each column can only contain one pivot, so in order for A to have a pivot in every row, it must have at least as many columns as rows: m\leq n.
This says that, for instance, \R^2 is too small to admit an onto linear transformation to \R^3.

subsection.title: Comparison
subsection.p:
One-to-oneversus onto Ontoversus one-to-one The above expositions of one-to-one and onto transformations were written to mirror each other. However, one-to-one and onto are complementary notions: neither one implies the other. Below we have provided a chart for comparing the two. In the chart, A is an m\times n matrix, and T\colon\R^n\to\R^m is the matrix transformation T(x)=Ax.
\parbox{2.5in}{\centering% \textbf{$T$ is one-to-one}\\[3mm] $T(x)=b$ has \emph{at most one solution} for every $b$.\\[3mm] The columns of $A$ are linearly independent.\\[3mm] $A$ has a pivot in every column.\\[3mm] The range of $T$ has dimension $n$. }\qquad\parbox{2.5in}{\centering% \textbf{$T$ is onto}\\[3mm] $T(x)=b$ has \emph{at least one solution} for every $b$.\\[3mm] The columns of $A$ span $\R^m$.\\~\\[3mm] $A$ has a pivot in every row.\\[3mm] The range of $T$ has dimension $m$. }

example.title: Functions of one variable
example.p: The function \sin\colon\R\to\R is neither one-to-one nor onto.
The function \exp\colon\R\to\R defined by \exp(x) = e^x is one-to-one but not onto.
The function f\colon\R\to\R defined by f(x)=x^3 is one-to-one and onto.
The function f\colon\R\to\R defined by f(x)=x^3-x is onto but not one-to-one.

example.title: A matrix transformation that is neither one-to-one nor onto
example.p: Let A = \mat{1 -1 2; -2 2 -4}, and define T\colon\R^3\to\R^2 by T(x) = Ax. This transformation is neither one-to-one nor onto, as we saw in this and this .

figure.caption: A picture of the matrix transformation T. The violet plane is the solution set of T(x)=0. If you drag x along the violet plane, the output T(x) = Ax does not change. This demonstrates that T(x)=0 has more than one solution, so T is not one-to-one. The range of T is the violet line on the right; this is smaller than the codomain \R^2. If you drag b off of the violet line, then the equation Ax=b becomes inconsistent; this means T(x)=b has no solution.

example.title: A matrix transformation that is one-to-one but not onto
example.p: Let A be the matrix A = \mat{1 0; 0 1; 1 0}, and define T\colon\R^2\to\R^3 by T(x) = Ax. This transformation is one-to-one but not onto, as we saw in this and this .

figure.caption: A picture of the matrix transformation T. The range of T is the violet plane on the right; this is smaller than the codomain \R^3. If you drag b off of the violet plane, then the equation Ax=b becomes inconsistent; this means T(x)=b has no solution. However, for b lying on the violet plane, there is a unique vector x such that T(x)=b.

example.title: A matrix transformation that is onto but not one-to-one
example.p: Let A be the matrix A = \mat{1 1 0; 0 1 1}, and define T\colon\R^3\to\R^2 by T(x) = Ax. This transformation is onto but not one-to-one, as we saw in this and this .

figure.caption: A picture of the matrix transformation T. Every vector on the right side is the output of T for a suitable input. If you drag b, the demo will find an input vector x with output b. The violet line is the null space of A, i.e., solution set of T(x)=0. If you drag x along the violet line, the output T(x) = Ax does not change. This demonstrates that T(x)=0 has more than one solution, so T is not one-to-one.

example.title: Matrix transformations that are both one-to-one and onto

figure.caption: Counterclockwise rotation by 90^\circ is a matrix transformation. This transformation is onto (if b is a vector in \R^2, then it is the output vector for the input vector which is b rotated clockwise by 90^\circ), and it is one-to-one (different vectors rotate to different vectors).

note.title: One-to-one is the same as onto for square matrices
note.p: We observed in the previous that a square matrix has a pivot in every row if and only if it has a pivot in every column. Therefore, a matrix transformation T from \R^n to itself is one-to-one if and only if it is onto: in this case, the two notions are equivalent.
Conversely, by this and this , if a matrix transformation T\colon\R^m\to\R^n is both one-to-one and onto, then m=n.

subsection.p: Note that in general, a transformation T is both one-to-one and onto if and only if T(x)=b has exactly one solution for all b in \R^m.
